subject: Career
title: The Compounding Effect of Early Negotiation
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Compounding Effect of Early Negotiation.

hook.text: A $5,000 difference in starting salary doesn't sound life-changing. Over 30 years, it's $600,000+.

buildup.text: Raises, bonuses, and retirement contributions are percentages of your base. A higher base compounds.

discovery.text: Every 3% annual raise is 3% of a bigger number. The gap widens every single year.

twist.text: This is why negotiating your first salary matters most. The first base sets the trajectory.

climax.text: Linda Babcock calculated the lifetime cost of not negotiating a first offer at over $500K.

quiz.question: Why is negotiating your first salary so important?
options: All future raises compound on that base
